1.q_string: Which of the following liquid pairs shows a positive deviation from Raoult's law?

An ideal solution of two liquids \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) is placed in a cylinder containing piston. Piston is pulled out isothermally so that the volume of the liquid decreases but that of vapours increases. Negligibly small amount of liquid was left and mole fraction of \(\mathrm{A}\) in vapour is \(0.4\). If \(\mathrm{P_{\mathrm{A}}^{\circ}=0.4 \mathrm{~atm}}\) and \(\mathrm{P_{\mathrm{B}}^{o}=1.2 \mathrm{~atm}}\) at the experimental temperature, which of the following is the total pressure at which the liquid is almost evaporated?

Two liquids \(\mathrm{X}\) and \(\mathrm{Y}\) on mixing form an ideal solution. At certain temperature, the vapour pressure of the solution containing \(3\) moles of \(\mathrm{X}\) and \(1\) mole of \(\mathrm{Y}\) is \(550 \mathrm{~mmHg}\). But when \(4\) moles of \(\mathrm{X}\) and \(1\) mole of \(\mathrm{Y}\) are mixed, the vapour pressure of the solution thus formed is \(560\) \(\mathrm{mmHg}\). The vapour pressure of the pure liquid \(\mathrm{X}\) is:

Two liquids \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) are mixed at temperature \(\mathrm{T}\) in a certain ratio to form an ideal solution. It is found that the partial pressure of \(\mathrm{A}\), i.e. \(\mathrm{P_{A}}\) is equal to \(\mathrm{P_{B}}\), the pressure of \(\mathrm{B}\) for liquid mixture. What is the total pressure of the liquid mixture in terms of \(\mathrm{P_{A}^{0}}\) and \(\mathrm{P_{B}^{0}}\)?
For an ideal solution in which \({p}_{{A}}{ }^{0}>{p}_{{B}}{ }^{0}\), the plot of total pressure \(({p})\) verses the mole fraction of \(A\) at constant temperature in the vapour phase is:

Direction: Consider the following statements and select the correct option.

(I) The concentration of \(\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}\) will increase in a solution of \(\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{OH})_{3}\) when \(\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]\)decrease (Given \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{sp}}\) of \(\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{OH})_{3}\) is \(4 \times 10^{-18}\) at \(298 \mathrm{~K}\)).

(II) In a mixture of \(\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}\) and \(\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{OH}\) in water, when a further amount of \(\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{Cl}\) is added, the \(\mathrm{pH}\) of mixture will decrease.

(III) An aqueous solution of \(\mathrm{NH}_{4} \mathrm{I}\) and \(\mathrm{HCO}_{2} \mathrm{~K}\) will be basic and acidic respectively.

q_option: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A).
1.q_string:
Directions: In the following question, there are two statements Assertion (A) and Reason (R). Consider both the statements independently and mark your answer.

Assertion (A): Vapour pressure is a colligative property.

Reason (R): According to Raoult's law, for dilute solutions containing non-volatile solute, the relative lowering of vapour pressure is equal to the mole fraction of solute.

\(100\ \mathrm{ml}\) aqueous solution (\(\mathrm{i}\)) containing \(0.0365 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{HCl}\) and \(400 \mathrm{ml}\) of \(10^{-2} \mathrm{M}\) aqueous solution (ii) of \(\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\)ions are mixed. The molarity of \(\mathrm{Cl}^{-}\)ions in resulting solution is:
Which of the following solutions shows maximum depression in freezing point?

A solution containing \(6 \mathrm{~g}\) of a solute dissolved in \(250 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of water gave an osmotic pressure of \(4.5 \mathrm{~atm}\) at \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). Calculate the boiling point of the solution. The molal elevation constant for water is \(0.52^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) per \(1000 \mathrm{~g}\).

Freezing point of an aqueous solution is \(-0.186^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). Elevation of boiling point of same solution would be:

\(\left(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{b}}=0.512 \mathrm{~K}\right.\) molality\(^{-1}\) and \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{f}}=1.86 \mathrm{~K}\) molality\(^{-1})\)

For a very dilute solution of a non-volatile solution in a volatile liquid, the variation of a \(\mathrm{V.P}\) of Solution \(\mathrm{(P)}\) with \(\mathrm{\frac{M_{1}}{M_{2}}}\) can be shown as below where \(\mathrm{M_{1}~ \&~ M_{2}}\) are m.wts, of solvent and solute respectively. Which of the following is true of given weights of solvent \(\mathrm{\left(\mathrm{W}_{1}\right)}\) and solute \(\mathrm{\left(\mathrm{W}_{2}\right)}\)?

The vapour pressure of pure liquid \(\mathrm{A}\) is \(10\) torr and at the same temperature, when \(1 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{B}\) solid is dissolved in \(20 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{A}\), its vapour pressure is reduced to \(9.0\) torr. If the molecular mass of \(\mathrm{A}\) is \(200\ \mathrm{amu}\), then the molecular mass of \(\mathrm{B}\) is:

Two elements \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) form compounds having molecular formulae \(\mathrm{AB}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{AB}_{4}\). When dissolved in \(20.0 \mathrm{~g}\) of benzene, \(1.0 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{AB}_{2}\) lowers the freezing point by \(2.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), whereas \(1.0 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{AB}_{4}\) lowers the freezing point by \(1.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The molal depression constant for benzene in \(1000 \mathrm{~g}\) is \(5.1\). Calculate the atomic masses of \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) are:
The van't Hoff factor of \(\mathrm{BaCl}_{2}\) at \(0.01 \mathrm{M}\) concentration is \(1.98\). The percentage of dissociation of \(\mathrm{BaCl}_{2}\) at this concentration is:

1.1:
Direction: When a liquid is completely miscible with another liquid, a homogeneous solution consisting of a single phase is formed. If such a solution is placed in a closed evacuated vessel, the total pressure exerted by the vapour, after the system attained equilibrium, will be equal to the sum of partial pressures of the constituents. A solution is said to be ideal if its constituents follow Raoult\&aposs law under all conditions of concentrations, i.e. the partial pressure of each and every constituents is given by \(p_{i}=x_{i} p_{i}\).

Where \(p_{i}\) is the partial pressures of the constituent \(i\), whose mole fraction in the solution is \(\mathrm{x}_{i}\) and \(\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{i}}{ }^{0}\) is the corresponding vapour pressure of the pure constituent.

Since both the components of an ideal binary liquid system follow Raoult's law of the entire range of the composition, the partial pressure exerted by the vapours of these constituents over the solution will be given by

\(p_{A}=x_{A} p_{A}{ }^{0} \quad \ldots\) (i)

\(p_{B}=x_{B} p_{B}{ }^{0} \quad \ldots\) (ii)

Where \(x_{A}\) and \(x_{B}\) are the amount fractions of the two constituents in the liquid phase and \({p}_{{A}}{ }^{0}\) and \({p}_{{B}}{ }^{0}\) are the respective vapour pressures of the pure constituents. The total pressure \(({p})\) over the solution will be the sum of the partial pressures. The composition of the vapour phase \(\left({y}_{{A}}\right)\) can be determined with the help of Dalton's law of partial pressures.
